awd_titl_txt: Combining Statistical Process Control and Optimization via Simulation for Robust Sensor Network Design in the Presence of Sensor Measurement Error
awd_abstract_narration:
For sensor network design, an optimization method is often used to determine how many sensors to install and where to physically install them. One stream of research is to assume a known functional relationship (usually a regression line) among sensor measurements with normally distributed noise. This assumption does not hold for systems with complex dynamics such as traffic transportation or environmental monitoring. Even when a process simulation is used to capture complex dynamics, it is often assumed that estimated performance measures from stochastic simulation are accurate and there is no false alarm (i.e., no sensor measurement error). A sensor network found under these assumptions may produce unacceptably high false alarm rates, which eventually makes the decision maker abandon the sensor network. This project develops statistical monitoring and controlling methods for raising an alarm when a sensor network of a complicated system detects abnormal behaviors such as a contaminant spill in a water quality monitoring network. Then it develops efficient simulation-based optimization algorithms to determine the number of sensors and their locations when stochastic simulation is used to estimate multiple performance measures. Finally this project combines the statistical methods and the simulation-based optimization to design the optimal sensor network while controlling false alarm rates. This research is interdisciplinary across manufacturing, quality control, simulation and environmental engineering; and the composition of the research team broadens the participation of underrepresented groups in research and teaching. The results from this research are applicable to many application areas and thus will benefit the U.S. economy and society. 

The objective of this project is to develop methods that will be useful in identifying an optimal sensor network quickly and accurately in the presence of sensor measurement error for a complicated system whose in-control and out-of-control observations are obtained through stochastic process simulation. This project considers a potentially large-scale process with general marginal and general correlation structure, which can broaden application fields of statistical process control (SPC) methods; and develops SPC techniques whose control limits neither require modeling of an underlying process nor trial-and-error calibration. It also develops a combined framework of SPC and discrete optimization via simulation when multiple performance measures exist. Finally it facilitates knowledge transfer from IE/OR to non-traditional IE/OR fields by applying the resulting combined algorithms to the water quality monitoring problem.

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this research is to develop methods that will be useful in identifying an optimal sensor network fast and accurately in the presence of sensor measurement errors for a complicated system whose observations are obtained through stochastic process simulation. A good example is a water quality monitoring problem where concentration levels of a contaminant spill event at potential sensor locations are obtained through process simulation, accounting for hydrodynamics and contaminant transport with random spill events and rain intensities at each location. 

In a surveillance sensor network, placing sensors at every possible location is not necessarily good because the resulting sensor network could generate an overwhelming amount of data and cause tremendous difficulty in data communication and analysis. In addition, the resulting sensor network produces unacceptably high false alarm rates unless it is carefully combined with a good monitoring method. For example, a border patrol sensor network with thousands of sensors would be useless if it triggers an alarm about every 44 seconds because it is impossible to send manpower to check every alarm. Thus, a robust and easy-to-implement spatiotemporal monitoring along with an efficient simulation optimization method is needed. 

To achieve these goals, the project (i) develops spatio-temporal monitoring charts whose control limit determination does not require heavy modeling of (possibly high-dimensional) underlying processes that exhibit substantial nonnormality and a stochastic dependency (temporal or spatial correlation) structure; (ii) develops efficient discrete optimization via simulation (DOvS) algorithms for a generic objective function subject to stochastic constraints on secondary performance measures; and (iii) finally combines the monitoring methods with the DOvS algorithms to design the optimal sensor network while controlling false alarm rates. An application to the water quality monitoring network design for a river system is considered.

For (i), we propose a set of reduced-dimension (RD) control charts that perform dimension reduction during the data acquisition process by spatial scanning unlike existing methods which conduct the dimension reduction as a post-processing step. The proposed methods avoid computational difficulties and possibly high communication costs. We derive a theoretical measure that characterizes the performance difference between the RD approach and the full observation approach and show that the RD approach has little performance loss under several commonly used spatial models while enjoying all the benefits of implementation. Then we develop an efficient score statistic, called the S3T statistic, to detect the emergence of a spatially and temporally correlated signal from either fixed-sample or sequential data. 

For (ii), we show that sensor locations in a surveillance network are sensitive to the variability of sensor measurement errors and the measurement errors must be considered when designing the locations of sensors. Then we develop an algorithm called the Confidence-Set based Constrained Bayesian Optimization (CSCBO), which models performance measures as Gaussian processes (GP) and provides a flexible and easy-to-implement framework to handle noisy black-box constraints. One of the difficulties in sensor placements is that decision variables are high-dimensional binary variables and thus a typical distance measure for a GP such as the Euclidean distance does not properly capture the similarity among solutions. To overcome this issue, we introduce the Wasserstein similarity metric as a distance measure among different solutions.

Finally, for (iii), the S3T statistic is combined with CSCBO to identify the optimal sensor placement while controlling the false alarm rate. The combined procedure is applied to the Altamaha River in the presence of random sensor measurement error. Resulting sensor networks for the Altamaha River with a high or low variability of sensor measurement errors are given in the attached figure. 

Out of this grant, total 11 publications were produced along with several presentations, posters and seminars in conferences, companies and universities. Three students (1 undergraduate and 2 Ph.D. students) have worked on this project: the undergraduate student continued his study in a graduate school and graduated with a Master degree; a Ph.D. student graduated in May, 2019 and currently works at Uber; and the other Ph.D. student is currently continuing her study as a 3rd-year Ph.D. student.
